Learn how to use DataService for queryin: Learn how to use DataService for querying data from DynamoDB tables.
The `DataService` is the query side of t: The `DataService` is the query side of the CQRS pattern, providing efficient read operations for data stored in DynamoDB. It handles all read operations from the data table (the read model) which is optimized for queries.
Before using the DataService, you need t: Before using the DataService, you need to set up the CommandModule as described in [the CommandService section](./command-service.md).
The `getItem` method returns a set of at: The `getItem` method returns a set of attributes for the item with the given detail/primary key. If there is no matching item, `getItem` does not return any data and there will be no item element in the response.
The `listItemsByPk` method returns one o: The `listItemsByPk` method returns one or more items matching the partition key. It supports filtering, pagination, and sorting.

Only retrieve the attributes you need to: Only retrieve the attributes you need to reduce data transfer
Always paginate large result sets to avo: Always paginate large result sets to avoid memory issues
Consider caching static or slowly changi: Consider caching static or slowly changing data
Design your keys to support your query p: Design your keys to support your query patterns efficiently
Always check if the item exists before u: Always check if the item exists before using it
The `publish` method publishes command d: The `publish` method publishes command data to the data table. This is typically called internally by the framework's data sync handlers, but can be used directly when implementing custom synchronization logic.
This method is primarily used internally: This method is primarily used internally by the framework. In most cases, you should use `CommandService.publishSync()` or `CommandService.publishAsync()` which automatically handles data synchronization.
Removes version suffix from sort key: Removes version suffix from sort key
Preserves original creation metadata (cr: Preserves original creation metadata (createdAt, createdBy, createdIp)
Stores the data in the data table: Stores the data in the data table
